Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of MIRTH: A Novel Catheter-Based Intramyocardial Ventricular Remodeling Procedure

Trial_Design.evidence: Animals were randomly assigned to receive the MIRTH intervention or serve as controls.

Participants.evidence: juvenile Yorkshire swine with either healthy myocardium or ischemic cardiomyopathy

Intervention.evidence: Animals were randomly assigned to receive the MIRTH intervention or serve as controls.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in left ventricular performance, assessed by contractility and mechanical efficiency, over a 90-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed with sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not applicable.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 33 animals were randomised: 17 with healthy myocardium and 16 with ischemic cardiomyopathy.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Nine of 12 healthy animals survived to 90 days, with two deaths attributed to unrelated bacterial sepsis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: MIRTH significantly improved left ventricular performance in cardiomyopathic animals, with increased contractility and mechanical efficiency (p < 0.05).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to myocardial erosion were observed, although two early implants failed due to suture abrasion.

Funding.evidence: Supported by the Division of Intramural Research, National Heart Lung and Blood Institute, National Institutes of Health USA (grant Z01-HL006040).
